Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cardiopulmonary Bypass Flow Rates on Renal Function

Trial_Design.evidence: In this nonblinded, parallel-arm trial, 36 adult patients undergoing cardiac surgery at a Swedish hospital were randomised

Participants.evidence: 36 adult patients undergoing cardiac surgery at a Swedish hospital

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either high flow (2.9 l · min–1 · m–2, n = 19) or standard flow (2.4 l · min–1 · m–2, n = 17) during CPB

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated whether a higher-than-standard CPB flow improves renal blood flow, oxygen demand–supply relationship, and function, and reduces tubular injury.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was renal blood flow, measured by para-aminohippuric acid clearance, over 60 minutes.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by eGFR and left ventricular ejection fraction using an online tool.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 36 adult patients undergoing cardiac surgery at a Swedish hospital were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: randomised to receive either high flow (2.9 l · min–1 · m–2, n = 19) or standard flow (2.4 l · min–1 · m–2, n = 17) during CPB

Result_Outcome.evidence: High flow increased systemic oxygen delivery (100 [95% CI, 60 to 141] vs. 31 [1.9 to 65] ml · min–1 · m–2; P < 0.001)

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by Swedish State, ALF-agreement, Swedish Heart and Lung Foundation, and Gothenburg Society of Medicine.
